importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating when the latest developments regarding Trump's potential provision of Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine were reported.

importantTimeframes.approximateTimeFrameStart: two weeks prior to the meeting with Zelensky
importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe during which Putin promised a meeting in Budapest, suggesting a strategic delay in de-escalation efforts and signaling potential shifts in diplomatic momentum.

keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump did not rule out sending Tomahawk cruise missiles to Ukraine during his call with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
Trump has not committed to providing the weapons during his scheduled meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, though the possibility remains open.
Zelensky and his aides have described Tomahawk missiles as potentially turning the tide of the war and as a strategic leverage tool to pressure Putin into negotiations.
Putin opposed the idea, arguing that the missiles could damage the US-Russian relationship and threaten major Russian cities, and claimed they would not meaningfully impact the battlefield.
Trump's administration has prepared plans to deploy the weapons if he decides, emphasizing that he can act at any time.
The US administration believes the threat of sending Tomahawks is a lever in broader diplomatic efforts to end the war, not an immediate escalation.
Some US officials remain cautious about escalation risks, though they note prior escalatory steps did not significantly worsen the conflict.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is the central political figure whose stance on sending Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine determines a major foreign policy decision, influencing both U.S.-Ukraine and U.S.-Russia relations.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Putin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Putin's opposition to the missile deployment reflects Russian strategic concerns about escalation and regional security, making him a key counterpoint in diplomatic negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Volodymyr Zelensky
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Zelensky sees the Tomahawk missiles as a potential turning point in the war, and their discussion with Trump underscores Ukraine's strategic leverage in peace negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Tomahawk cruise missiles
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The missiles represent a significant escalation in capability and are central to the geopolitical tension between the U.S., Ukraine, and Russia.

namedEntities.name: Budapest
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Putin promised a meeting in Budapest to delay a potential peace agreement, indicating a strategic diplomatic venue being used to manage escalation.

namedEntities.name: Middle East negotiations
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump's growing interest in diplomacy in the Middle East may influence his approach to Ukraine, showing a broader shift in foreign policy priorities.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump has not ruled out sending long-range Tomahawk cruise missiles to Ukraine during his conversation with Russian President Vladimir Putin, despite Putin's opposition and concerns over escalation. While Trump has not committed to providing the weapons during his meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, the administration has prepared plans to deploy them if deemed necessary. Zelensky views the missiles as a strategic tool to pressure Russia into negotiations, while Putin argues they would damage the U.S.-Russia relationship and threaten major Russian cities. The prospect of a meeting in Budapest, brokered by Putin, suggests a temporary diplomatic pause, though Trump continues to maintain the threat as leverage in broader diplomatic efforts to end the war.
title: Trump hasnâ€™t closed the door on sending Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine
